entry.title: Drupal Camp NJ: Progressively Decoupled Drupal for Everyone
entry.summary: Recently, the Office of Digital Learning (Eberly College of Science at Penn State) participated in the ninth consecutive Drupal Camp NJ, hosted at Princeton University. The weekend witnessed d
entry.content:
Recently, the Office of Digital Learning (Eberly College of Science at Penn State) participated in the ninth consecutive Drupal Camp NJ , hosted at Princeton University. The weekend witnessed developers and industry professionals collaborating on a number of Drupal initiatives through informative presentations, networking opportunities, and engaging training sessions.

Demonstrating their progress since Drupal Camp NJ 2019, the ODL team continued where they left off with their discussion on decoupling Drupal. Specifically, Michal Potter and I joined ELMS:LN lead developer, Bryan Ollendyke (College of Arts and Architecture - Penn State) and Rebecca Goodman (Branch Chief, Web at U.S. National Archives and Records Administration / NARA) to present work on web components.

Web components are a set of web platform APIs that allow you to create custom, reusable, HTML tags to use in web pages and web apps. Because they’re built using web standards, they will work across all modern browsers and within any JavaScript library or framework that works with HTML. The team has been actively working to implement web components across a number of projects, including a custom suite of authoring tools (HAX ), Drupal, WordPress, Grav CMS and more.

Bryan Ollendyke jump-started the conversation with a great introduction and Michael Potter and I showcased our implementation of web components across several custom web themes. The highlight of the talk was Rebecca Goodman announcing that her web team at NARA had started implementing web components into their work-flow by successfully placing a branding bar across several of their existing web properties.

Overall, feedback was extremely positive. The audience contained a wide variety of technical backgrounds. Developers quickly understood how they could reduce technical debt across their projects, graphic designers saw how their interactions with Content Management Systems could be simplified, and project managers realized how this approach could reduce timelines of maintenance and enhancement across the board.

entry.title: Get Decoupled at Drupal Camp NJ
entry.summary: This past weekend (February 1-3) the Office of Digital Learning (Eberly College of Science at Penn State) participated in the eighth consecutive Drupal Camp NJ, hosted at Princeton Universi
entry.content:
This past weekend (February 1-3) the Office of Digital Learning (Eberly College of Science at Penn State) participated in the eighth consecutive Drupal Camp NJ , hosted at Princeton University. The annual event brings developers and industry professionals from varying backgrounds and skill-levels together to share all things Drupal through engaging presentations, co-working sessions, and networking.

This year there were a number of great discussions to get involved with, but one topic continued to dominate the conversation - decoupling Drupal. Decoupling Drupal essentially means separating Drupal’s front-end (theme layer) from it’s back-end (data/content layer) using a custom JavaScript framework. While there are still some discussions as to which framework is ‘best’ when decoupling Drupal, the general consensus is that the decoupled method is becoming an industry-wide movement.

Jesus Manuel Olivas (Head of Products at weKnow ) showcased decoupling tools like Gatsby and Tome . These tools assist in creating static sites by decoupling Drupal’s theme and just using Drupal for content creation.

Saurabh Chugh and Surendra Singh hosted a discussion, ‘Decoupling Patterns, Services and creating an enterprise level editorial experience’ where they also emphasized using decoupled applications to display content.

Saurabh Chugh and Surendra Singh hosted a discussion, ‘Decoupling Patterns, Services and creating an enterprise level editorial experience’ where they also emphasized using decoupled applications to display content.

Our team demonstrated decoupled development when Michal Potter and Charles Lavera joined ELMS:LN lead developer, Bryan Ollendyke (College of Arts and Architecture - Penn State) to present work on web components. Specifically, the trio discussed the tooling they use to quickly generate and publish their components onto the web (WCFactory / Drupal webcomponents module ). In addition, Bryan explored the future of content-authoring with a completely headless authoring experience called HAX.

Get decoupled at Drupal Camp NJ and check out our presentation below, then use this link ---> and try HAX for yourself!

entry.content: Are you searching for a creative, interactive, and engaging way to have students submit details about an assignment or project they’re working on? entry.content:
Michael is an educational technologist who brings a decade’s worth of experience building websites and applications to the edtech space. His non-traditional path began at Penn State where he earned his BA in Political Science. From there, Michael joined a local venture capital group where he was involved with many different companies and handled everything from sales, to product development, to logistics and shipping. When one such company lost their only web developer, Michael was tapped to takeover the programming responsibilities and the rest is history. Michael was immediately hooked with web development and begin soaking up every piece of information the web could offer.

Since then, Michael has gained a wealth of experience in the full stack of web applications. His skillset is most notable in the area of front-end development and the Drupal framework. He has a passion for writing code, learning how to code, and mentoring fellow programmers. Michael has a unique gift for connecting, inspiring, and empowering others.

Innovative, forward thinking, risk taking are some of the reasons Michael wanted to work at ODL. His goal is to create technology and applications that remove barriers between educators and students. Michael believes that the web can enable people to change their lives for the better.

entry.title: Carly Dreibelbis
entry.content:
I have always been obsessed with visuals. When I was a kid I would go through my mom’s magazines, find an image I loved, check with my mom to make sure she didn’t need the article on the back, then clip it out and safely tuck it away in a flat, waxed-cardboard box under my bed - only to find out years later that my mom secretly snuck in my room and downsized my collection to keep it under control.

These days, I apply my passion for visual arts to graphic design and photography. I soak up inspiration all around me, and still tear out magazine ads and tuck them away for reference. I strive to visually present the facts and discipline of science with creativity, quality, technology and whenever possible… a bit of humor. I am always looking for new ways to approach courses, graphics, and content to successfully visually communicate concepts with an audience.

If I’m not behind a computer screen, you can find me outside with a camera by my side or in mad scientist mode in my kitchen - while tripping over a hungry cattle dog vacuum.

entry.title: Phys 212
entry.content:
Description

Calculus-based introduction to classical electricity and magnetism, including such topics as, electric charge and electric fields, Gauss's law, electric potential, capacitance, current, resistance, and circuits, magnetic fields, and fields due to currents, induction and inductance, magnetism of matter, Maxwell's equations, and electromagnetic oscillations

Prerequisite

Math 140, Phys 211 Concurrent: MATH 141

Textbook

Physics for Scientists and Engineers: A Strategic Approach by Knight, 4th edition. This course will cover (in parts) chapters 22-32 and Chap 16 from the Phys 211 book.

Course Topics

Unit Topic(s)
1 Electric Force and Field
2 Electric Potential & Current
3 DC Circuits
4 Magnetism
5 Electromagnetic Induction
6 AC Circuits
7 Electromagnetic Waves

Course Schedule

This is a 4 credit course that is fairly intensive with course work due almost every day. A standard week contains three phases: exploratory phase, problem solving phase and revision phase. The exploratory phase of a giving week overlaps with the revision phase of the previous week. The final assignment for a week are due on Tuesday of the next week allowing time to review and discuss.

Days Wednesday Thursday Friday Saturday Sunday Monday Tuesday
Exploratory Phase Problem Solving Phase Revision Phase / Exploratory Phase (Next Week)
Graded Assignments due Discussion Board - 1st Post Reading Quiz Tutorial / Lab - 1st Draft Discussion Boards - Replies Peer Reviews Tutorial / Lab - Final Version
Live Sessions Office Hours Learning Sessions

Not every week will contain all different types of assignments. For an exam week, the exam is on Thursday (on the material of the previous weeks).

Most of the material is posted ahead and it is entirely possible for you to adjust this schedule to fit better with your own work/study schedule.

Reading Quiz

We will be using an online computer grading system called MasteringPhysics (https://www.pearsonmylabandmastering.com/) to do reading quiz . Access to MasteringPhysics is provided in the PSU custom book in the bookstore.

The reading quiz are due early in the week and they are meant to be places to first learn the material, not a place to “test” your knowledge. Most of the questions are “tutorials” that will walk you through how to solve problems. You get immediate feedback when answering questions and many questions provide hints.

Tutorial

Each week, we will have a tutorial. There are three options on how to do the tutorials:

  • Print it and write your answer by hand, take a picture (or a scan) and submit.
  • Use a blank sheet, write your answer by hand clearly numbering them. Take a pic or scan and submit.
  • Using a tablet, write your answer by hand on the tutorial pdf and submit.

In this type of assignments, we will grade your work and not just your answer. If you have a real professional scanner, that will work great. If we have to use a phone we recommend to use scanning app which do better than just pictures.

Labs

The laboratories (8 in total) are designed to provide you with hands-on experience with the material being investigated in class as well as teaching data sensemaking and observational experimental methods. See the list of learning objectives for more details. All of those skills and topics learned in the lab may be tested in the exams. The lab will be using the IOLab device various sensors together with the accompanying software. While the lab component is officially only worth 10% of the grade, a zero on all labs will result in a letter grade of D at best irrespective of all other course work.

Peer-Review

It is very beneficial for students to see each other works and to receive and give feedback. Therefore, a first draft of the weekly tutorial and lab is required to be posted every Saturday. You will then be randomly assigned to peer-review multiple of your peers and give feedback on their work (not grade their work which is only a draft anyway). The instructors will also review each draft submission and help out where needed. The tutorial and lab will then be resubmitted for grading every Tuesday. The peer-review is graded and is part of the quiz grade. As you will see, there are some points every week in the quiz assigned to a peer-review question.

Discussion Boards

Maybe the most important part of this course is the weekly discussion board. You will be assigned a team and you will need to post and reply to your teammates.

Often the post will include three parts:

  • Your answers and reasoning to a couple of conceptual questions on the material
  • Comments/questions on your work on the tutorial
  • Comments/questions on your work on the lab

Instructor and TA will provide feedback in the discussion boards. The discussion boards are the online analog of a lecture where the students discuss with continuous instructor feedback.

The first post of the discussion is due on Wednesday but replies will continue as long as needed.

Quiz

There will be individual quizzes throughout the semester with questions that closely resembled the exams. These are graded on correctness. You get two tries and the best score is kept. The quiz will also self-reflections questions and this is where the points for the peer-review will be attributed.

TA Sessions

These are required live discussions once a week where we will review previous material and look ahead to the upcoming week. These sessions will be hosted by teaching assistanta and the instructor. We will have multiple time options.

Discussions with Professor

I will host a discussion hour on Thursdays (not graded or required but very useful). These may be recorded but I will need students to start the discussions!

Exams

There will be two midterm exams. Both midterms are worth the same: 20% each for a total of 40%.

Exams will be closed book. Relevant physical constants and formulae will be provided. Calculators, cellular phones and other communication devices are NOT allowed and the exam will be designed such that they are not needed. The exams will be based on the assigned reading in the textbook, the material covered in course content, the quizzes, discussion boards and the laboratories/tutorial.

Each exam will be delivered through Canvas. All exams are proctored using Examity which allow you to take the exam anywhere and to schedule at any time (in the appropriate time window where the exam is opened).

Grading

Your grade in the course will be based on your performance in the labs/tutorials, on the quizzes, on the discussion boards/wrap-ups/peer-reviews and on the exams with the following weights:

Assignment % Score
Reading Quiz 5%
Quiz 5%
Discussion Boards 5%
Labs 10%
Tutorials 5%
Midterms 40%
Final 25%
Concept Surveys 2%
TA Sessions 3%
Total 100%

Grading Scale

Letter Grade % Score
A 93-100%
A- 90-92%
B+ 87-89%
B 83-86%
B- 80-82%
C+ 77-79%
C 70-76%
D 60-69%
F < 59%

entry.content:
***This Page is Continually Being Updated***

Need Help?

Calling for Faculty Mentors

If you are a comfortable with Canvas and want to share your knowledge with others, let us know and we can help direct others to you. We have had many faculty members who either teach online or use Canvas all the time who are already helping other faculty who might not be up to speed with the tools. Let us know if you are willing to help and we can help get you connected!

Frequently Asked Questions

Video How To: How Do I Find My Canvas Space Online?

Video How To: How Do I Find My Zoom Room?

Video How To: How Do I Access My Penn State Media Space? (Coming Soon)

Get Started

It may seem overwhelming when you think about moving your course online quickly, but there are some steps that you can take that make it a little more manageable.

  • Put your syllabus online. You can upload your syllabus as a Word Document or a PDF to Canvas so that students have access to all the important and relevant information about the course.
    • How to upload files to Canvas
  • Make a statement in your syllabus about what would happen if classes were cancelled, including how the class may change and how you will stay in contact with them.
    • Penn State Virus Info
  • If something does happen, get details about the event. Find out what Penn State is saying and the policies around the event.
  • Talk with your department. Departments may have unique strategies and plans for their own particular courses.
  • Communicate with students early and often. Use Canvas Inbox to mail students about changes that are coming and any details they need to know.
  • Make sure you set realistic goals for instruction. What can you move online and how do you ensure students will have structure and be accountable for their learning.
  • Determine course priorities. What do students really need to know?
  • Review your syllabus for places where instruction may change. How will you modify due dates and assignments? You will need to update your syllabus accordingly.
  • Realize that this is as tough on your students as it is for you. What will participation look like now and how you can be equitable and accommodating to all?
  • Make sure you continue to communicate with students and update them on details and changes they will need to know.

For more information, please contact our office.

Getting Your Course Online

Louis Leblond, instructor from Physics, shares his tips about how to move your course online.

How to Design an Online Course

Backward Design

Backward design is a pedagogical approach where instructors begin with the end, their learning outcomes, in mind. By identifying outcomes and the initial learning goals, instructors can figure out appropriate ways to fill in the required elements for instructions and make sure the content is aligned toward what the students need to learn to succeed in the course. Review the Backward Design Guide .

LinkedIn Learning

LinkedIn Learning, formerly Lynda.com has a nice tutorial about putting your course content online. Interested in taking your training program to the online space? In this course, join instructor Samantha Calamari as she steps through how to design engaging elearning content that connects with a diverse set of participants. To begin, Samantha helps you determine if elearning is the right approach for your training program. She then acquaints you with key instructional design methods and theories, explaining how to apply them in your design process. Next, she shows how to organize the learning experience and design content that effectively delivers information to learners. Discover how to approach tone and engagement, create an active learning environment, design assessments that enrich your learner's experience, and more.

Take the course: E-learning Essentials
